description.raw:
started py3 compat in response to issue #16

- `from __future__` and `future_builtins` added to all modules
- moved from `PKG` to `__package__` in `__init__.py`. I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way.
- all `print` functions coverted to py3 style (using `2to3`)
- `2to3` also changed a variety of interface details (`iteritems` to `items`, `xrange` to `range` etc)
- switched from `optparse` to `argparse` throughout. more consistent use of `gdarchive` in modules.
- removed redundant `die` definitions and moved `die` into `_util.py`
- package wide `__version__` imports from `__init__.py` allows command line interface to report correct package version. removed CVS-style `__version__ = '$Revision$'` definitions from  modules.

Also:
- added `sizes` command to `genomedata-info`

All tests pass. BUT should really write a test cases that directly test the command line interfaces, maybe something like: http://dustinrcollins.com/testing-python-command-line-apps.
description.html:
started py3 compat in response to issue #16

  • from __future__ and future_builtins added to all modules
  • moved from PKG to __package__ in __init__.py. I didn't enforce py2.7+ anywhere because there are a variety of ways to do that and I'm sure Michael has a favorite way.
  • all print functions coverted to py3 style (using 2to3)
  • 2to3 also changed a variety of interface details (iteritems to items, xrange to range etc)
  • switched from optparse to argparse throughout. more consistent use of gdarchive in modules.
  • removed redundant die definitions and moved die into _util.py
  • package wide __version__ imports from __init__.py allows command line interface to report correct package version. removed CVS-style __version__ = '$Revision$' definitions from modules.

Also: - added sizes command to genomedata-info

All tests pass. BUT should really write a test cases that directly test the command line interfaces, maybe something like: http://dustinrcollins.com/testing-python-command-line-apps.
